citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live animals.
citations.narrative:
Several enclosures used to transport animals did not have projecting rims or hand holds. A transport enclosure housing 2
Ringtails, a transport enclosure housing 2 Rock Hyrax, and a transport enclosure housing an African Crested Porcupine
did not contain projecting rims or adequate handholds. A lack of projecting rims on primary transport enclosures can allow
for inadequate ventilation particularly when the cages are stacked when placed on the cart to move between the auction
floor and holding area, and lack of handholds can cause unintentional contact between the handler and the animal during
transport. Correct by 11/16/2023 by ensuring that all primary transport enclosures for subpart F animals contain projecting
rims or other devices on the exterior walls to prevent obstruction of the ventilation and provide adequate handholds for
lifting animals without tilting or risk of contact with the animal.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee. This inspection was conducted in Mount Hope, Ohio.
Additional Inspectors:
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.137(a) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live animals. 
Several enclosures used to transport animals did not have projecting rims or hand holds. A transport enclosure housing 2 
Ringtails, a transport enclosure housing 2 Rock Hyrax, and a transport enclosure housing an African Crested Porcupine 
did not contain projecting rims or adequate handholds. A lack of projecting rims on primary transport enclosures can allow 
for inadequate ventilation particularly when the cages are stacked when placed on the cart to move between the auction 
floor and holding area, and lack of handholds can cause unintentional contact between the handler and the animal during 
transport. Correct by 11/16/2023 by ensuring that all primary transport enclosures for subpart F animals contain projecting 
rims or other devices on the exterior walls to prevent obstruction of the ventilation and provide adequate handholds for 
lifting animals without tilting or risk of contact with the animal. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee. This inspection was conducted in Mount Hope, Ohio. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
